title: Nitsche's Finite Element Method for Model Coupling in Elasticity
summary: This paper presents a Nitsche finite element method for coupling elastic models, focusing on the hybridized approach of Burman et al. The method is used to model interfaces with bending and membrane stiffness, as well as strong and cohesive coupling between the beam-truss interface and the membrane.
methodology: The paper uses a finite element method based on the Nitsche framework, which involves introducing an auxiliary interface variable and using hybridization to derive a weak formulation. The method is then used to model interfaces with bending and membrane stiffness, as well as strong and cohesive coupling.
research_outcomes: The paper presents numerical examples illustrating the properties of the model and method, including results for stretching, contact, and cohesion.

title: Performance Analysis of Flat Plate and Evacuated Tube Collectors
summary: This paper conducts a thermal analysis on the performance of solar water heating systems with flat plate and heat pipe evacuated tube collectors, comparing their efficiency and solar fraction under various operating conditions. The study finds that evacuated tube collectors are more efficient than flat plate collectors.
methodology: The authors used T*SOL Simulation software to conduct a thermal analysis of the two collector configurations under different weather conditions and volume flow rates.
research_outcomes: The study found that evacuated tube collectors have higher monthly solar fractions (up to 80%) compared to flat plate collectors (up to 64.6%). The hourly tank outlet temperature peaked in November for both systems, with the maximum temperatures being 87 °C and 71.2 °C for ETC and FPC, respectively.

title: Degradation of Diclofenac Sodium in Microbial Fuel Cells
summary: This paper investigates the degradation of diclofenac sodium using microbial fuel cells. Although machine learning or AI methods are not explicitly mentioned, the study uses statistical methods to analyze data and draw conclusions about the effects of pH and temperature on diclofenac sodium degradation.
methodology: The researchers used a two-chamber glass MFC reactor with anaerobic sludge and potassium ferricyanide as an electron acceptor. They measured the output voltage and removal rate of diclofenac sodium at different initial concentrations, pH levels, and temperatures.
statistics: HPLC was used to determine the concentration of diclofenac sodium, and a standard curve was drawn to relate peak area to concentration.
research_outcomes: The study found that weak acid conditions (pH=5.5) accelerated the degradation of diclofenac sodium, while low temperatures inhibited its degradation. The removal rate of diclofenac sodium was up to 30.73% after two weeks of treatment.

title: Analytical and Numerical Investigation on Depth and Pipe Configuration for Coaxial Borehole Heat Exchanger, A Preliminary Study
summary: This paper presents a preliminary study on the optimization of coaxial borehole heat exchangers (CBHEs) for geothermal energy harvesting. The authors develop a numerical solver to investigate the flow regime within CBHEs, accounting for both convective and conductive heat transfer. The study focuses on determining the most optimized design for CBHEs, providing maximized thermal output by exploiting the geothermal gradient.
methodology: The authors use a three-step solver to investigate the flow regime within CBHEs, solving the Navier-Stokes equation and energy equation with a finite difference solver. The temperature distribution and velocity field are calculated at every time step, and the resulting temperature is used to compute the thermal output.
research_outcomes: The study determines that a CBHE configuration can be optimized for maximized thermal output by accounting for both convective and conductive heat transfer. The authors provide a numerical solver to investigate the flow regime within CBHEs, which can be used to determine the most optimized design.

title: Dynamic and Friction Parameters of an Industrial Robot: Identification, Comparison and Repetitiveness Analysis
summary: This paper focuses on the identification and comparison of dynamic parameters in industrial robots. The authors use a dynamics model to study the robustness of an industrial manipulator, identifying joint friction changes during robot operation. They propose a method for estimating temperature and related friction variation using experimental data from two robots.
methodology: The authors use a Lagrangian formulation to obtain the dynamic model of the robotic arms, which is then used to estimate the inertial and friction parameters. The Least Square Method is employed to identify the dynamical parameters.
research_outcomes: The study shows that joint friction changes during robot operation can be identified using a dynamics model. A method for estimating temperature and related friction variation is proposed, which can be used for predictive maintenance programs or human-robot interaction.

title: Performance Evaluation of Single and Multi-Objective Calibration in Rainfall-Runoff Modelling
summary: This paper evaluates the performance of single and multi-objective calibration methods for rainfall-runoff modelling using the MIKE 11 NAM model. The study focuses on the Gin catchment in Sri Lanka, where accurate rainfall-runoff simulations are crucial to minimize flood hazards and manage water resources efficiently. Although machine learning is not explicitly used in this paper, it highlights the importance of proper model calibration and the use of multiple evaluation criteria for hydrological modelling.
methodology: The study uses a lumped conceptual rainfall-runoff model (MIKE 11 NAM) to simulate rainfall-runoff processes at the catchment scale. The model is calibrated using four single-objective and eleven multi-objective schemes, with performance evaluated using three criteria: Nash-Sutcliffe coefficient (NSE), percent bias (PBIAS), and coefficient of determination (R^2).
statistics: Nash-Sutcliffe coefficient (NSE), percent bias (PBIAS), and coefficient of determination (R^2)
research_outcomes: The study shows that multi-objective calibration yields more accurate and consistent simulations, covering different aspects of the hydrograph simultaneously. The combination of four objective functions satisfying all performance evaluation criteria resulted in overall best performance.

title: Zero-crossing Point Prediction Technology of CFI Based on A New Adaptive LS Algorithm
summary: This paper proposes a new adaptive least square algorithm for predicting zero-crossing points in controlled fault interruption (CFI) technology. The algorithm improves upon the traditional LS method by reducing truncation errors caused by approximating the attenuated DC decaying component, and achieves high accuracy even with noisy data.
methodology: The paper uses a new adaptive least square algorithm to predict zero-crossing points in CFI technology. The methodology involves solving a system of equations to obtain parameters of the short circuit current.
research_outcomes: The proposed algorithm achieves high accuracy in predicting zero-crossing points, even with noisy data. It has potential applications in improving the breaking capacity of circuit breakers.

title: Research on the Method of Improving the Flow Field Quality in the Elbow of the Water Flow Standard Device Based on the CFD Numerical Calculation Method
summary: This paper presents a computational fluid dynamics (CFD) numerical calculation method to study the flow characteristics of fluid passing through elbows in water flow standard devices. The research focuses on improving the flow field quality by changing the turning angle and installing deflectors, but does not involve machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The CFD numerical calculation method is used to study the flow characteristics of fluid passing through elbows in water flow standard devices. The research involves establishing 3D geometric models of elbows, mesh generation, and parameter setting for numerical calculations.
research_outcomes: The results show that increasing the turning angle and installing deflectors can improve the flow field quality by reducing vortex and secondary flow. However, the effect of increasing the thickness of deflectors is not obvious.

title: Efficiency enhancement of solar cell collector using Fe3O4 / water nanofluid
summary: This paper investigates the performance of a photovoltaic thermal (PVT) collector using Fe3O4/water nanofluid as a coolant. The study aims to enhance the efficiency of PVT collectors, which are solar devices that produce both electricity and heat energy. The authors employed numerical simulations using ANSYS Fluent to investigate the effect of nanofluids on the performance of PVT collectors.
methodology: Numerical simulations using ANSYS Fluent
research_outcomes: The study found that using Fe3O4/water nanofluid as a coolant increased the overall efficiency of PVT collectors compared to water-cooling and non-cooling PV solar cells.

title: Photocatalytic Decolorization and Biocidal Applications of Nonmetal Doped TiO2: Isotherm, Kinetic Modeling and In Silico Molecular Docking Studies
summary: This paper investigates the photocatalytic performance and biocidal potential of nitrogen-doped TiO2 against textile dyes and microbial contamination. The study uses molecular docking to predict the biocidal mechanism, but does not involve machine learning or AI methods.
methodology: The study employs a sol-gel technique for synthesizing different mol% nitrogen-doped TiO2, followed by characterization using various techniques such as TGA, SEM, XRD, FT-IR, and DRS.
research_outcomes: The study finds that the best nanomaterial depicted 5.57 nm crystallite size, 49.54 m2 g−1 specific surface area, 11–40 nm particle size with spherical morphologies, and uniform distribution. The RB5 decolorization data fits well with the pseudo-first-order kinetic model.

title: Condition Assessment of Tower and Mast Structures Using the Combination of PCA with Cross-Validation
summary: This paper proposes a condition assessment approach combining principal component analysis (PCA) with cross-validation to evaluate the structural condition of tower and mast structures monitored within one cluster under changing environments. The method is effective in reducing the adverse effects of environmental temperature and speed load on the horizontal displacement monitoring data of tower and mast structures, but does not utilize machine learning or AI methods.
methodology: The proposed approach uses PCA to mitigate the influence of environmental factors on the displacement monitoring data, and cross-validation to evaluate the condition of all the tower and mast structures monitored within one cluster.
research_outcomes: The method is effective in reducing the adverse effects of environmental temperature and speed load on the horizontal displacement monitoring data of tower and mast structures.

title: Evaluation of Diethyl Ether as a Renewable Transport Fuel in Sudan
summary: This paper evaluates the potential of diethyl ether as a renewable transport fuel in Sudan. The study investigates physicochemical properties, copper corrosion test, and diesel engine performance of diethyl ether diesel blend fuels. The results show that addition of diethyl ether up to 20% improves the physicochemical properties of diesel, but there is no mention of machine learning or artificial intelligence methods used.
methodology: Experimental
research_outcomes: The study found that diethyl ether can be used up to 10% in diesel blend with no further changed in diesel engine design, and it improves the physicochemical properties of diesel.

title: Model based simulation of a CVT variator to analyse the slip characteristics of the CVT belt
summary: This paper presents a mathematical model using SIMULINK to analyze the slip characteristics of a Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT) variator. The study focuses on controlling clamping forces and improving transmission efficiency, with no mention of machine learning or AI methods.
methodology: The authors use a mathematical approach in SIMULINK to understand the relationship between clamping forces, frictional forces, slip experienced by the belt, and overall transmission efficiency.
research_outcomes: The study presents results on controlling clamping forces and improving transmission efficiency, but no specific outcomes related to machine learning or AI are mentioned.

title: Integrated Disturbance Observer Attitude Controller for a Satellite with Rotating Solar Array
summary: This paper presents a robust attitude control method based on disturbance observer for a satellite with rotating solar array. The proposed controller effectively estimates and compensates the external disturbance torque, improving the attitude control accuracy and stability.
methodology: The methodology involves designing a PD controller combined with a disturbance observer to estimate and compensate the external disturbance torque.
research_outcomes: The research outcomes show that the proposed controller can improve the control accuracy by one order of magnitude, reducing the angle accuracy from 0.1deg to 0.02deg and the angular velocity accuracy from 0.02deg/s to 0.004deg/s.

title: Assessing Performance of Multipurpose Reservoir System Using Two-Point Linear Hedging Rule
summary: This paper assesses the performance of a multipurpose reservoir system using a two-point linear hedging rule. The study focuses on optimizing water release for various purposes, including municipal and irrigation supply, while minimizing environmental impact. Although machine learning or AI methods are not explicitly used in this research, it explores innovative techniques in water resource management.
methodology: Simulation is a mathematical technique used to compare the performance of reservoir operation using hedging rule with standard operating policy.
research_outcomes: The results show that the application of hedging rule significantly improved the reliability of water supply and firm power production compared to standard operating policy.

title: Safety of Nanoclay/Spring Water Hydrogels: Assessment and Mobility of Hazardous Elements
summary: This paper assesses the safety attributes of nanoclay/spring water hydrogels by evaluating their elemental composition and mobility. The study finds that while some hazardous elements are present in the hydrogels, they are not bioavailable at normal doses, making them safe for topical application.
methodology: The authors used Inductively Coupled Plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurements to assess the elemental composition of pristine ingredients and nanoclay/spring water hydrogels. They also performed in vitro cation release studies using a Franz diffusion cell system.
research_outcomes: The study found that while some hazardous elements are present in the hydrogels, they are not bioavailable at normal doses, making them safe for topical application.

title: A Multi-Electrode Pixel Structure for Quick-Response Electrowetting Displays
summary: This paper proposes a new multi-electrode pixel structure to improve the response speed of electrowetting displays. The proposed structure was simulated using COMSOL Multiphysics software, and the results showed that it can effectively improve the response time compared to traditional single-electrode structures.
methodology: The authors used a dynamic model of the three-dimensional EWD realized by numeric methodology, simulating the transient motion of oil using COMSOL Multiphysics software.
research_outcomes: The proposed multi-electrode pixel structure can effectively improve the response time of electrowetting displays compared to traditional single-electrode structures.

title: Total Repair Cost Simulation Considering Multiple Probabilistic Measures and Service Life
summary: This paper analyzes the total maintenance cost for public houses in South Korea using probabilistic and deterministic methods. The study evaluates the effect of each repair process on the total maintenance cost, considering the coefficient of variation (COV) of extended service life.
methodology: The study uses a probabilistic approach to analyze the maintenance cost, considering the variability of extended service life through repair. The deterministic method is also used for comparison.
research_outcomes: The results show that the total maintenance costs can be adjusted by extending the initial repair timing to the largest possible extent for the highest-repair-cost process.

title: Electric Vehicles: Problems or Solutions
summary: This paper discusses the current directions of vehicle developments, barriers and opportunities for using electric vehicles instead of conventional vehicles. The authors investigate the future market prospects of various types of EVs, with a focus on economics and environmental impact.
methodology: The methodology involves analyzing the performance of powertrain systems, comparing the effectiveness of electric vehicles to conventional vehicles, and discussing the challenges associated with widespread adoption of EVs.
research_outcomes: The authors conclude that electric vehicles have several advantages over conventional vehicles, including reduced air pollution and noise emission. However, they also highlight the need for a more efficient charging infrastructure and the development of new power systems to support the increasing demand for EVs.

title: A Modeling of Lead-Acid Battery for Electric Vehicles and Simulation Utilizing C MEX S-Function in Matlab/Simulink
summary: This paper models a lead-acid battery for electric vehicles and simulates its behavior using C MEX S-Function in Matlab/Simulink. The study focuses on analyzing the battery's performance and determining the optimal arrangement of batteries to satisfy the voltage and capacity requirements of an electric vehicle.
methodology: The paper uses a mathematical model to describe the behavior of the lead-acid battery, which is then simulated using C MEX S-Function in Matlab/Simulink. The simulation process involves deriving a circuit to the state-space equation and implementing it in C programming language.
research_outcomes: The study finds that series circuits increase their voltage and parallel circuits increase their ampere. It also determines the optimal arrangement of batteries for electric vehicles, which is essential for improving their performance.

title: Gyro-Sensor-Based Vibration Control for Dynamic Humanoid-Robot Walking on Inclined Surfaces
summary: This paper investigates the angular-pitch velocity of a humanoid robot walking on an inclined surface, using a gyro sensor to control the ankle and hip motors. The study focuses on balancing the robot's gait pattern and reducing vibrations.
methodology: The authors used a frequency-domain analysis of the angular-pitch velocity to explain the reasons behind the instabilities of dynamic humanoid-robot walking on inclined surfaces.
research_outcomes: The study found that a nonlinear nature of the motor torque, due to a force induced by the slope, gives rise to harmonics of the fundamental walking frequency. These harmonics are the origin of the unstable robot walking.

title: An Automated Retrofittable Street Light Solar Panel Cleaner
summary: This paper presents a solution for cleaning solar panels on streetlights, focusing on designing and developing an automated retrofittable system that requires minimal human interference. The proposed system uses a sensor-based mechanism to clean the panels based on information collected from sensors, including timers, voltage sensors, current sensors, and humidity sensors.
methodology: The methodology involves designing and developing a sensor-based cleaning mechanism that can be added as a retrofit to existing streetlight solar panels. The system uses a pair of wiper blades mounted on lead screws rotated by servo motors powered by the panel's current.
research_outcomes: The proposed system increases power generation by up to 50% after cleaning, and reduces the operational hours for the Stand-alone Solar streetlight (SASSL) by up to 23%. The system also prevents soiling of the panels, reducing electric generation and erratic charging of the battery.

title: A NUMERICAL ANALYSIS OF DIFFERENT METHODS FOR STRENGTHENING BEAMS MADE OF GLULAM WITH CFRP FIBER COMPOSITES
summary: This paper presents a numerical analysis of different methods for strengthening beams made of glulam with CFRP fiber composites. The study focuses on the mechanical properties and behavior of composite materials in construction, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence techniques.
methodology: The authors used numerical calculations performed in the ANSYS program to analyze the behavior of beams made of glulam with CFRP fiber composites. The study involved creating 3D models and simulating various reinforcement methods.
research_outcomes: The results show that using composite materials can reduce deflection values compared to an unreinforced beam, making it a beneficial method for strengthening beams. However, the most effective method is using a composite tape glued horizontally between the last and second last lamella.

title: Silicon nanowires decorated with platinum nanoparticles were applied for photothermal-enhanced sonodynamic therapy
summary: This paper presents a novel approach to cancer treatment using silicon nanowires decorated with platinum nanoparticles for photothermal-enhanced sonodynamic therapy. The Si-Pt nanocomposites exhibit strong chemodynamic therapy and sonodynamic therapy effects, making them suitable for combined cancer therapy.
methodology: The methodology involves the synthesis of Si-Pt nanocomposites using in situ reduction of Pt nanoparticles on silicon nanowires. The resulting material is then tested for its ability to generate reactive oxygen species under ultrasound irradiation.
research_outcomes: The study demonstrates that Si-Pt NCs can produce ROS and •OH under US conditions, making them suitable for sonodynamic therapy. The results show that Si-Pt NCs exhibit higher SDT efficiency than commercial TiO2 nanoparticles.

title: Environmental Inefficiencies of Short Sea Shipping Vessels by Optimization Processes Based on Resistance Prediction Methods
summary: This paper analyzes the environmental performance of Short Sea Shipping vessels and quantifies the consequences of inaccurate resistance prediction methods. The authors compare three estimation methods, including a simplified early decision-making tool (J. Mau method) and Computational Fluid Dynamics simulations, to evaluate their accuracy in estimating calm water resistance.
methodology: The paper uses optimization processes based on resistance prediction methods to analyze the environmental performance of Short Sea Shipping vessels. The authors apply three estimation methods: J. Mau's method, Holtrop and Mennen's method, and Computational Fluid Dynamics simulations.
research_outcomes: The study shows that inaccurate resistance prediction methods can lead to significant deviations in expected sustainability and air emissions. The results provide useful insights for uncertainty management in further research and policy-making purposes.
